prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for refusing to let my neighbors park in my free spot
To cut a long story short my neighbor has about 4 cars, husband, wife + kids. I have lived inside this house for the past 18 years, they moved in about 3/4 years ago. At first I had no issues letting them park in my parking spot because I had no car. I’m not an asshole so I let them park their car there for years free of charge. 

A few months ago I had the wife approach me and ask me if she could take half of my front garden to build herself a porch, I said no. I live in the UK so we don’t have porch where you can just park your car, it’s all street parking. 

After I turned down her request she has stopped greeting me whenever she says me, fine I don’t care. I’d like to note at this point her family members were still using my parking spot. 

Today she approaches me and informs me that she will start building her driveway taking up half of my property. I’d like to note that I don’t own the house, I just rent it. The council owns the house. She tells me that the council has given her permission to take up half of my front garden to build her driveway, lol ok. I again informed her that I don’t consent and that she cannot go ahead with her building plan. 

This kind of entitlement has enraged me so I called up my brother who had a car and told him to come and park in my parking spot, he did. As soon as my brother parked his car, my neighbor the husband came out yelling at my brother telling him to move his car that was when I told him that he and his family members could no longer park on my spot. 

The whole driveway issues confuses me and I will be calling the council later today to try and stop this crazy woman taking half of my garden!
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong in this situation. The scenario involves the author's neighbor using their parking spot for years, then things escalating when the neighbor tries to take part of the front garden for a driveway.

First, the author lives in the UK on a rented property. The neighbor, who has four cars, has been using the author's spot for years when the author didn't have a car. Now that the author has a car, they're enforcing the spot. The neighbor then tries to build a driveway on half the author's garden without consent. The author confronts this by having their brother park there, leading to a confrontation.

So, key points: The author allowed the neighbor to use the spot out of kindness. The neighbor's family continued using it even after the author's refusal to let them take the garden. The author's response was to block the spot with their brother's car when the neighbor was trying to build.

In terms of legal standing, since the author is a tenant, the property might be owned by the council. The neighbor claiming permission from the council might be an issue. But the author's main issue is about the parking spot, which they've used as a courtesy. The neighbor's entitlement in trying to take the garden without consent is a problem. The author's action of blocking the spot could be seen as protecting their property rights. However, using a family member's car to enforce this might be a bit aggressive, but given the neighbor's actions, maybe the author feels justified.

The question is about whether the author is in the wrong. The neighbor has been using the spot without permission for years, so the author has the right to stop that. The neighbor's attempt to take the garden is another issue. The author's response is to take back their spot, which they have the right to do. So maybe the author isn't in the wrong. But maybe the way they did it (bringing a brother's car) is a bit confrontational. However, the neighbor was already acting unkindly by not greeting and trying to take the garden. So the author's actions are a defense of their property. Therefore, likely answer B.
